column4: generally that key is supposed to send integers to /proc/acpi/toshiba/lcd (on my toshiba)
is there something I can try to wake it up?
try sending echo 'brightness : 5 > /proc/acpi/toshiba/lcd
replace toshiba with dell in your case (should work)
echo 'brightness : ' 5 > /proc/acpi/dell/lcd
the second apostrophe also
though on my asus laptop it is /proc/acpi/asus/brn
just found  out that on my laptop it works  like this; sudo -i to  get into root shell and then echo 5 > /proc/acpi/asus/brn
try that last command with dell in place of asus
i dont have a dell
maybe your acpid isnt being passed that event anymore
trying the manual way will at least tell you whether your backlight is ok
can you tell me the contents of ls -l /proc/acpi/dell (pastebinit please)
can you pastebin ls /proc/acpi
pastebin it please dont flood here
thats funny our directories are similar except for the fact that you dont have a machine specific like dell (i have asus)
did anything change for this to happen?
are you working on a line of code for me?
im trying to
i just found out; the brightness control on the 620 is totally hardware controlled not OS. So you probably have to take it to dell for fixing
its the up arrow  prolly
Jack_Sparrow uh a simple reboot fixed the whole screen brightness issue ...I'd be happy, but I'm too busy being embarrassed. LOL
good for you :)
